articles.headline: Responding to Spill, Obama Mixes Regret With Resolve
articles.snippet: President Obama balanced a defense of his handling of the spill with an unusual presidential self-critique.
articles.abstract: President Obama balanced a defense of his handling of the spill with an unusual presidential self-critique.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama uttered three words on Thursday that many of his 43 predecessors twisted themselves into knots trying with varying degrees of success to avoid: “I was wrong.”

articles.headline: Adviser to Stars Named in Fraud
articles.snippet: Kenneth I. Starr was accused of diverting money from his A-list clients to purchase a lavish Manhattan apartment.
articles.abstract: Kenneth I. Starr was accused of diverting money from his A-list clients to purchase a lavish Manhattan apartment.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was the moneyman to the stars, entrusted with managing fortunes for the likes of Wesley Snipes, Sylvester Stallone and Annie Leibovitz.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and James Barron

articles.headline: F.D.A. Weighs Penalties in Drug Recall
articles.snippet: A Johnson & Johnson unit that recalled millions of children’s Tylenol bottles may face criminal penalties.
articles.abstract: A Johnson & Johnson unit that recalled millions of children’s Tylenol bottles may face criminal penalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Johnson & Johnson unit that recalled millions of bottles of liquid children’s Tylenol and other pediatric medicines last month may face criminal penalties, product seizures or other sanctions, an official from the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday.

articles.headline: House Votes to Allow ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Repeal
articles.snippet: The 234-to-194 vote and an earlier vote in a Senate panel amount to major steps toward dismantling the 1993 law.
articles.abstract: The 234-to-194 vote and an earlier vote in a Senate panel amount to major steps toward dismantling the 1993 law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted Thursday to let the Defense Department repeal the ban on gay and bisexual people from serving openly in the military, a major step toward dismantling the 1993 law widely known as “don’t ask, don’t tell.”
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Safety Rules Can’t Keep Up With Biotech Industry
articles.snippet: Biotechnology labs are filled with imponderable hazards yet are subjected to fewer regulations than most factories.
articles.abstract: Biotechnology labs are filled with imponderable hazards yet are subjected to fewer regulations than most factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are the highly trained, generally well-paid employees in the vanguard of American innovation: people who work in biotechnology labs. But the cutting edge can be a risky place to work.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: Oxford Tradition Comes to This: ‘Death’ (Expound)
articles.snippet: All Souls College is scrapping its one-word exam, on which applicants demonstrated their intellectual flexibility.
articles.abstract: All Souls College is scrapping its one-word exam, on which applicants demonstrated their intellectual flexibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England  The exam was simple yet devilish, consisting of a single noun (“water,” for instance, or “bias”) that applicants had three hours somehow to spin into a coherent essay. An admissions requirement for All Souls College here, it was meant to test intellectual agility, but sometimes seemed to test only the ability to sound brilliant while saying not much of anything.

articles.headline: Strike Forces Honda to Shut Plants in China
articles.snippet: A strike at a crucial parts factory is the clearest sign yet of growing labor unrest in a country at the cornerstone of companies’ global supply chains.
articles.abstract: A strike at a crucial parts factory is the clearest sign yet of growing labor unrest in a country at the cornerstone of companies’ global supply chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  A strike at a crucial parts factory has forced Honda to shut down all four of its joint venture assembly plants in China. It was the clearest sign yet of growing labor unrest in a country that now stands at the cornerstone of companies’ global supply chains.

articles.headline: Strike in China Highlights Gap in Workers’ Pay
articles.snippet: A strike at a Honda factory has come to symbolize income inequality, inflation and soaring property prices in China.
articles.abstract: A strike at a Honda factory has come to symbolize income inequality, inflation and soaring property prices in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOSHAN, China — After years of being pushed to work 12-hour days, six days a week on monotonous low-wage assembly line tasks, China’s workers are starting to push back.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and David Barboza

articles.headline: BP Engineers Making Little Headway on Leaking Well
articles.snippet: Amid mixed messages about problems and progress, officials said they would continue for another 48 hours before considering other options.
articles.abstract: Amid mixed messages about problems and progress, officials said they would continue for another 48 hours before considering other options.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  BP engineers struggled Friday to plug a gushing oil well a mile under the sea, but as of late in the day they had made little headway in stemming the flow.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Spain News Sends Stocks Into Decline
articles.snippet: Fitch cut Spain’s credit rating, saying that the country’s debt will probably weigh on the country’s growth.
articles.abstract: Fitch cut Spain’s credit rating, saying that the country’s debt will probably weigh on the country’s growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the American markets ever needed a reminder of how volatile Europe has made them this month, they got it on Friday.

articles.headline: Teaching Work Values to Children of Wealth
articles.snippet: In a tight job market, affluent parents worry as much about how to teach their children the value of work and money as they do short-term swings in their portfolios.
articles.abstract: In a tight job market, affluent parents worry as much about how to teach their children the value of work and money as they do short-term swings in their portfolios.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven D. Hayworth, chief executive of Gibraltar Private Bank and Trust, is thrilled that his daughter will be working this summer at a women’s clothing store before heading to college in the fall. It is not the particular job that pleases Mr. Hayworth. Rather, he is hoping his daughter will make the connection between how much she earns each day and what that will buy.
